section.title: Gist of Functions: Definition and Notation

subsection.title: Defining a Function
subsection.p: A function function is a rule that may be in the form of a graph, or a table of values or a formula. It may even be a sentence or a set of instructions. A function takes an input value and uses the rule to create an output value.
Function notation functionnotationnotationfor functions looks like this: f(\text{input})=\text{output}

But, instead of writing the words input and output we usually use variables, like x and y. Then we define in words what the variables actually mean or represent. Most often the notation will look something like this: f(x)=y

Inside the parentheses is the independent variablevariableindependentindependent variable, in this example it is x. Outside the parentheses, on the other side of the equals sign, is the dependent variablevariabledependentdependent variable. In this case ours is y.

statement.p:
Suppose f is the rule that takes the area of a circle as its input and then outputs the radius of the circle.
What is the correct way to write this rule in function notation?
Which is the independent variable?
In the equation f(100) \approx 5.64, what are the possible units for the number 5.64?

li.p: The correct answer is . We were told that the function takes the area as the input, so the area must be in the parentheses.
The correct answer is . This function uses the area of the circle as the input, and the radius depends on the area.
The correct answer is . The number 5.64 was the output of the function which is the radius of the circle. The radius of a circle must have a length unit.

subsection.title: Inputs have unique outputs
subsection.p: An important property of functions is that any single input value can only have one output value, and that output is unique.

example.p: When you buy a car it usually comes with a sticker on the window that includes information about the fuel efficiency. Cars are tested on a track under controlled conditions and most likely the manufacturer has all kinds of graphs and tables for the efficiency measures for various speeds of the car.

Let E be the fuel efficiency, in miles per gallon, of a car traveling at s miles per hour. Because knowing the speed of the vehicle determines its efficiency, we can use function notation to write E = f(s) That is, efficiency is a function of speed.

figure.caption: Graph of f(s): Fuel Economy versus Speed

example.p: The input is the speed, s, and the output is the efficiency, E so we can write an ordered pair (s, E) or (s, f(s)).
It should make sense that a car can only have one efficiency at any given speed (one input, one output) since it cannot get 10 and 20 at the same time.
Also, during the controlled test, if the car traveling at a speed of 5 has an efficiency of 12 then 5 always gets us 12. The value 12 is the unique output associated with the input of 5.

However, it is possible there are multiple inputs that give you the same output. From the graph we see that a fuel efficiency of 25 can be attained by traveling at a speed of about 16 and also at about 70.

subsection.p: Graphically, a relation must pass the vertical line testvertical line test to be a function. When the test is passed, we say the function is well definedwell defined.

statement.p: Suppose f is a function. Which of the following situations are possible?

solution.p: The correct answer is . A function cannot have the same input value giving two different output values. However, it may have two different input values giving the same output value.

subsection.title: Describing functions with intervals
subsection.p: A function may have many different characteristics:

li.p: Output values may increase or decrease.
The graph may curve up or curve down.
The outputs may be positive or negative.

subsection.p: When describing these characteristics for a function, we typically refer to an intervalinterval (connected section) of the input axis, or to a particular value of the input where something interesting occurs. Figure

We can use inequalityinequality symbols to describe an interval where a function has a particular property, like increasing for 5\lt s\lt55. This means the function values are getting bigger as the inputs change from 5 to 55.

Another characteristic we can describe with inequalities is concavityconcavity. We say a function is concave up if its graph curves upward from left to right, and that it is concave down if it curves downward from left to right.

example.p:
The efficiency graph has varying concavity depending on what section of inputs we use:
concave down for 5\lt s\lt60.
concave up for 60\lt s\lt75.

subsection.p: The word evaluateevaluate means to use a known input value to find the output value. Evaluating a function looks like this:f(35)It means, Find the result of choosing 35 as the input. The expression f(35) represents the output, which we can see from the graph.

subsection.title: Average Rate of Change
subsection.p: Average rate of change is very important topic of this course. You will see it over and over again in various forms. Basically it means slope, but it's more than that. It's also a notation and a concept that sets the stage for calculus.

Using our vehicle efficiency function we know the car's efficiency at various speeds. A change in speed may or may not have much affect on the efficiency. The average rate of change of the efficiency is actually the measure of slope between any two speeds.
The calculation is always a change in output divided by a change in input.

statement.p: [@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/dGpvT5eC/width/413/height/331/border/888888" width="413px" height="331px" style="border:0px;" width="431px" height="313px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
The average rate of change of the efficiency of the vehicle is affected by different intervals of the speed of the vehicle.

li.p: What is the average rate of change of the efficiency on the interval 10 \leq s \leq 20?
What is the average rate of change of the efficiency on the interval 60 \leq s \leq 72?

subsection.p: Gathering information from the function we can calculate changes in efficiency due to changes in speed.

Using function notation we write \frac{\Delta f}{\Delta s}\amp=\frac{f(10)-f(20)}{10-20} \amp=1.1 The number 1.1 (notice it is positive) means that between speeds of 10 and 20, the car's efficiency is increasing at an average rate of 1.1 per 1.

On a different interval we could write \frac{\Delta f}{\Delta s}\amp=\frac{f(60)-f(72)}{60-72} \amp=-0.8 The number -0.8 (notice it is negative) means that between speeds of 60 and 72, the car's efficiency is decreasing at an average rate of -0.8 per 1.

The little triangle symbol \Delta is also very important. It means, change in. Therefore based on our example, \Delta f means change in efficiency and \Delta s means change in speed. Together the symbol \frac{\Delta f}{\Delta s} is called average rate of change.

subsection.title: Units
subsection.p: Units are the names of the quantities we are counting. They give meaning to the numbers or values we use in an expression.
When you measure the width of a room, the tape measure might count 10.5. The number 10.5 is the value and is the unit.
In car efficiency example the units of efficiency are (miles per gallon) and the units of speed are (miles per hour). Therefore the average rate of change for this example will have units of .
Because slope is just rise over run a fraction, the units of the average rate of change are also a fraction.
